bestBHT.bht: When Jesus cried out Ελω or Ελε, the people mistakenly thought he called for Elijah, misunderstanding the words as Ελιαν φωνε. This reveals their ignorance or willful misinterpretation. Jesus's loud and clear voice, along with the words he uttered, attracted the attention of those nearby, leading to speculation about whom he was calling upon.

Archibald T. Robertson: He calleth Elijah (Ελειαν φωνε). They misunderstood the Ελω or Ελε (my God) for Elijah.
John Gill: Behold he calleth Elias; whom they ignorantly, or wilfully took for Eloi.
The loud voice of Jesus, and the words he uttered.
Some of them that stood by, when they heard [it].

bhtAttempts.bht: In Mark 15:35, the people misunderstood when Jesus cried out Ελω or Ελε, thinking that he was calling upon Elijah. This misunderstanding highlights their ignorance or willful misinterpretation of Jesus's words. The loudness and clarity of Jesus's voice, along with the words he uttered, caught the attention of those who stood by.

The people heard Jesus cry out Ελω or Ελε and mistakenly thought he was calling for Elijah. This misunderstanding reflects their ignorance or deliberate misinterpretation of his words. Jesus's loud and clear voice, along with the words he uttered, captured the attention of those who were nearby and sparked speculation about the identity of the one being called upon.

When Jesus cried out Ελω or Ελε, the people mistakenly thought he called for Elijah, misunderstanding the words as Ελιαν φωνε. This reveals their ignorance or willful misinterpretation. Jesus's loud and clear voice, along with the words he uttered, attracted the attention of those nearby, leading to speculation about whom he was calling upon.

The people who heard Jesus cry out mistakenly believed that he was calling for Elijah, misunderstanding the Ελω or Ελε as Ελειαν φωνε. This misinterpretation could be attributed to their ignorance or willfulness. Jesus's forceful vocalization and the specific words he spoke drew the attention of those standing nearby, leading to speculation about the individual he was summoning.

When Jesus cried out, the people mistakenly interpreted his words as Ελειαν φωνε, thinking he was calling for Elijah. This misunderstanding may have been due to their ignorance or deliberate misinterpretation. The loudness and clarity of Jesus's voice, along with the specific words he uttered, drew the attention of those who were present, sparking speculations about the figure he was invoking.
